data.title: Html intellisense closing tags already closed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create basic html page
2. Make several nested <section></section> tags after 3 the intellisense will continue to suggest and complete upon enter or tab to close the already closed <section> tag.

Here is an example, change the file type to html and attempt to add another section into .banner or .wrapper, the issue should reproduce.
[Example.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1024369/Example.txt)

data.title: Marketplace extension sorting
data.body:
In January, I published a Markdown extension [Markdown All in One](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=yzhang.markdown-all-in-one) in the vscode marketplace.

At that time, my extension was placed around the 16th when searching 'markdown'.
But as I keep improving my extension, it ranks 22nd now. That is a big difference as people won't see it if they don't scroll down the page.

Just like SEO,

> the earlier (or higher ranked on the search results page), and more frequently a site appears in the search results list, the more visitors it will receive from the search engine's users

The first extension in the results page has 110k downloads. But IMHO, it's because the positive feedback loop (I don't judge whether the extension itself is good or not). Being the first one receives many downloads, and then the huge download count keep it ranked first.

My friend once asked me why vscode can only preview Markdown in browser. I felt really confused why he asked that. And then he told me he just searched the markdown extension and found the first one had been downloaded so many times. So, he downloaded that extension and came to the question above (the only feature in a previous version of that extension).

As I know, Markdown preview is a out-of-box feature even in the earliest version of vscode.

So, I think the current sorting results are not good. It's said to be sorted by relevance, but I'm confused why some extensions are more 'relevant' than mine.

---

BTW, for language extensions, it would be better to have a officially recommended (not necessary officially maintained) extension for each language.
On the one hand, it's a good experience for users (no need to try and choose one from many similar extensions).
On the other hand, it can save the effort of extension authors to have one extension to contribute to.

data.title: Problem with extension using sqlite3
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: WINDOWS 8.1 64 BIT

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a extension
2. Add sqlite3 dependecy

When I try to debug the extension it shows this message " Cannot find module 'c:\Users\Rafael\workspace\nodespace\vscode-database\node_modules\sqlite3\lib\binding\node-v53-win32-ia32\node_sqlite3.node."

When I search for this folder in the extension project I only got this folder "node-v48-win32-x64"

Can somebody help me ? I tried building sqlite3 from source and nothing. Node version is 6.9.4 and npm 3.10.10

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.5|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|nord-visual-studio-code|arcticicestudio|0.2.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.1|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Blackboard|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-PastelsonDark|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-peel|gerane|0.0.2|
|rest-client|humao|0.14.1|
|crayon-vscode|jansenfuller|0.1.3|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.59|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.5|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.0.0|
|vscode-jsp|pthorsson|0.0.2|
|java|redhat|0.1.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.7.0|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.7.3|;


---

I'd like Code to refresh the editor window when I make a change to the file from outside (or some process modifies the file etc...) Currently it does not do that and I was unable to find a relevant setting. 

This is prone to overwrites etc. hence I'd like to have an option to either get a notification or have a config setting somewhere to opt-in/out of auto-refresh (or similar) capability.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file in Code
2. Change the file contents from an external program
3. Come back to Code
4. 
Expected: Editor window refreshes to reflect the changes done outside 
OR
There is a way to refresh the file (like a notification)

Actual: Editor couldn't care less.

data.body: Adding Xcode project and workspace extensions to default extension supported list so VS Code shows up in the "Open with..." menu context on Mac #27164

data.title: Adding xcodeproj and xcworkspace to the default CFBundleTypeExtensions for Mac
data.body: At the moment, VS Code isn't shown as a recommended application for opening xcode project (_xcodeproj_) and/or xcode workspace (_xcworkspace_) files. It's required sometimes to open those files and apply changes to them manually. [Atom](https://atom.io/) is currently shown as recommended applications. Although there's a workaround for this explained [here](https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/15030/how-can-i-add-a-new-application-to-the-open-with-menu), it'd be great if VS Code adds those extensions as its supported extensions for Mac so VS Code appears in "Open With" context menu for aforementioned extensions by default.

data.title: Variable substition: ${packagePath}

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In the spirit of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/396, please consider adding a new variable that can be used in launch.json and that will refer to the package directory (`packageRoot`) of the currently opened file within the editor.

This is going to be useful to reduce the number of profiles necessary to debug each package. As an example, here's what we have to do currently such that we can debug our tape unit tests directly from the code editor:

Given that we have a mono repo structure like this:

```
Root
  package.json
  Packages
    api
      package.json
      src
      dist
    orm
      package.json
      src
      dist
```

Given we develop in Typescript and we resolve the current file name using `${fileBasenameNoExtension}`, Given we have both a "api" package and a "orm" package in a git mono repo,
We are stuck doing this to debug our tests inside the code editor:

```
{
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "name": "Debug::api current test",
        "sourceMaps": true,
        "protocol": "inspector",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/tape/bin/tape",
        "args": [
          "${workspaceRoot}/packages/api/dist/_test/**/${fileBasenameNoExtension}.js"
        ],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/packages/api",
        "console": "internalConsole"
      },
      {
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "name": "Debug::orm current test",
        "sourceMaps": true,
        "protocol": "inspector",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/tape/bin/tape",
        "args": [
          "${workspaceRoot}/packages/orm/dist/_test/**/${fileBasenameNoExtension}.js"
        ],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/packages/orm",
        "console": "internalConsole"
      }
```

The request is for a variable that identifies the root directory of each package so that we could re-write our launch.json like this:

```
 {
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "name": "Debug unit test with tape",
        "sourceMaps": true,
        "protocol": "inspector",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/tape/bin/tape",
        "args": [
          "${packageRoot}/dist/_test/**/${fileBasenameNoExtension}.js"
        ],
        "cwd": "${packageRoot}",
        "console": "internalConsole"
      }
```

data.title: Improve autocomplete according to Node.js docs
data.body:
Hello,

my suggestion is to improve autocomplete according to Node.js docs, because sometimes it lacks of autocomplete in some places, for e.g.

```javascript
const dgram = require('dgram');
const server = dgram.createSocket('udp4'); // There's no autocomplete for udp4 and udp6
```

This is not only this place, there are more.

data.title: Allow selection of individual build/test tasks if multiple are defined

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
As it stands, having multiple tasks defined as "isBuildCommand": true or "isTestCommand": true does not make much sense as only the first defined task is executed (this is the behavior I have observed) when running "Tasks: Run Build Task" or "Tasks: Run Test Task". 

If multiple such tasks are defined, could the execution of "Run Build Task" or "Run Test Task" drop down a list of applicable tasks similar to how "Run Task" behaves?

data.title: PreLaunchTask: support passing parameters from configuration to preLaunchTask

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently when invoking preLaunchTask, the only possible is the task name. It would be great if properties in the associated configuration can be passed to preLaunchTask.

Scenario: 
  I am writing a pre-launch task to automate remote node.js debugging. The pre-launch task will launch the node.js process remotely and establish a SSH tunnel (port forwarding) back to local computer. And then debugger connects to that forwarded port to start debugging. 
  The node.js debugger port is specified in launch.json file, and there is no good way for the pre-launch task to get the debugger port. 

The problem can be solved if preLaunchTask can take parameters from the configuration. For example, tasks.json allow '$config.port' as args:

           {
                "command": "dotnet",
                "taskName": "prepareDebug",
                "suppressTaskName": true,
                "args": [ "/myhelper.dll", "debug", "start", "$config.port" ],
                "isBuildCommand": false,
                "showOutput": "always",
                "options": {
                    "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}"
                }
            }

@isidorn @weinand

data.title: Don't block file results on symbol results indefinitely
data.body: This PR implements the alternative solution discussed in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27152

data.title: When quick open is configured to include symbols, slow symbol results block file results

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Problem**

If `search.quickOpen.includeSymbols` is configured to true then OpenAnythingHandler will wait for `this.openSymbolHandler.getResults(searchValue)` to resolve. This is a problem if symbol results are slow because the OpenAnythingHandler is the only way to get file results.

**Ideal solution**

Stream file and symbol results in as they are found so the user is not blocked on slow results.

**Alternative solution**

Don't wait indefinitely for symbol results in the OpenAnythingHandler. If the results timeout, the user can always perform the dedicated OpenSymbolHandler quick open action.

2. Run the task.
3. Run another task. Can't run another task because the first task hasn't finished.
I would like a method to run an external task which is detached from the VS Code, ie it will not be monitored by VS Code. I have a lot of tools which run independently with their own GUI and it would be good to start them from with VS Code because they related to the code being edited.

data.title: Add better merge extension
data.body:
Adds the better merge extension to vscode proper. (https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=pprice.better-merge). This will enable decoration, code-lenses and commands for "standard" style merge conflicts. 

Notable changes:
 - `better-merge.*` command contributions changed to `merge-conflict.*` with same keybindings and functionality. 
 - Settings collapsed down to `merge-conflict.codeLens.enabled` and `merge-conflict.decorators.enabled`
 - Replace the single pass regex scanning of entire document, with line-by-line scanning, sans regex. 
 - Added localization (`package.nls.json` and `vcode-nls` usage) support
 - Remove the `git` extension decoration of merge blocks. 

Known TODOs: 
 - Performance measurements for large files. Maximum to test up to is 5mb as anything larger is not synchronized with extensions. 
 - It is possible to fire two scan **consumptions** from the same "origin" code, this mostly happens in `mergeDecorator.ts`, when a document is opened then active. The actual scan happens once as it is debounced via the delayer, BUT the merge decorators are sent to the document twice. I have a candidate fix in the works. 
 - Replace hard-coded decorator colors with something to get theme colors when available. 

Potential TODOs (probably future PRs) 
 - Support diff3 format

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the user settings, override with "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\Sysnative\\cmd.exe"
2. In the workspace settings, revert is back with     "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\Sysnative\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe"
3. Start a new integrated terminal - cmd.exe is run instead of powershell.exe. This is even after restarting VSC and closing and reopening the folder also.

data.title: Explorer: folders should act like the ones in Finder/Xcode on Mac
data.body:
As a Mac user, I expect all folders act the same behavior just like they do in Finder or Xcode:

1. click the folder: just select the folder (**not expands/collapses it**).
2. click the disclosure triangle: expands/collapses the folder.
3. `option + arrow-right/arrow-left` on a selected folder: expands/collapses all sub-folders in the hierarchy.
4. hold `option` and click the disclosure triangle: just like what `option + arrow-right/arrow-left` do to expands/collapses all sub-folders in the hierarchy.

Current behaviors which I did not expect:

1. Simply clicking the folder will expands/collapses the folder (should just select it).
2. Can't find a familiar way to expands/collapses all sub-folders in the hierarchy (using `option`).

I really do expect that VSCode team can fulfill this expectation in Explorer.

data.title: Support reopening session (all windows, tabs, etc.)
data.body:
I have multiple vscode windows open. Each window has a specific tab layout, with multiple files opened, from multiple projects, most of them not related to any project.

Ideally, I would like to quit (Ctrl + Q) vscode, so that when I start vscode again, it remembers all of that (window layouts, etc) and reopens all my files.
